body: Wow, what fun!  I will start to pick my way through this but in depth review will probably have to wait until the dev meeting week.  To help with the review, can you make sure that the IPEP is up to date with this design as well as all of the web services stuff.

Yes, I'll work on the IPEP and the web services first thing in the morning. I may end up combining the web service documentation (in the gist I wrote) with the IPEP. I think it presents the information more clearly.
IPEP updated!
@ccordoba12 might be interested in this PR. We are going to start writing tests now, if you are interested in writing some. This PR should be near ready to merge (after 1.0 release).

Hey @Zsailer, great work as usual! I haven't had time to thank you for your first `multidir` attempt. Without it I couldn't have been able to make my demo at SciPy :-) (One month of work for a 2 minutes demo, oh man :-)

Handlers and services API has changed a lot in this branch so it'll take me some time to update my branch and help you with some testing in our side.

How do you plan to write tests for this? Testing the handlers to get the right responses?

@ccordoba12 Thank you! I'm glad you could use the earlier PR to create your demo. I hope everything turned out well for you!

The new API and web service design here is well worth the update. We spent a lot of time thinking about the best way to restructure the APIs, and I think we got it right this time.

I think sending requests to the handlers and checking their responses is the best way to test. We want to create notebooks and delete them, create directories, navigate into directories, rename notebooks, start and restart kernels, etc. All these actions are direct responses from the handlers.

I'll be working on tests myself for the next couple weeks, so there is no pressure on your end. If you happen to write a test while using this branch, I'd love to use it. Otherwise, just feedback on how everything is working for you would be great as well. It's a big PR, so it helps me tremendously to have another person testing it out.

@dpsanders fixed the command line entry to a notebook that you mentioned in issue #3811.

 Just type:
`ipython notebook foo/bar/notebook.ipynb`
to open a notebook with the relative path `foo/bar`

If you want to start the dashboard tree in relative path:
`ipython notebook foo/bar`

If you want to start the server in a relative path:
`ipython notebook --notebook-dir=foo/bar`

This should all work with names that include spaces... just add quotes around the full argument.

@takluyver HI, welcome to CA! It would be great if you could help review the code for this PR as it relates to unicode and Python 3.  This PR does a lot with URLs, paths, notebook names - your careful eye for this stuff would be greatly appreciated.

> @takluyver HI, welcome to CA! It would be great if you could help review the code for this PR as it relates to unicode and Python 3. This PR does a lot with URLs, paths, notebook names - your careful eye for this stuff would be greatly appreciated.

Second approach is merge, break master and have fun :-)
Looking at it now.
PR Zsailer/ipython#2 has some of the easy changes I noted.

some more feedback: even with Thomas' changes merged, I'm getting some odd behavior here locally. For one, the pop-up blocker gets invoked in both FF and Chromium, whereas it doesn't do that on master.

Also, new notebooks get created, but they get redirected to a 404 - I'm diving into the code to fix this, so ping me on HipChat if you're working on that part right now, @Zsailer

Did you try a browser refresh?

Sent from my iPhone

@takluyver, maybe hold off on reviewing this for now. @ivanov is helping me clean up all the logic and add proper doc strings/comments. It's all pretty messy right now. After we do a full make-over of the PR, I'll ping you again for a final review. Thanks for your help today!
@Zsailer no worries, good luck.
hey @Zsailer, I'm not seeing my last commit from yesterday in here. The commit message was "clean up of get_os_path and its tests"
@ivanov Sorry, I hadn't pushed it yet. I started working on the session manager and forgot to push.
@ivanov Take a look at my last commit 'session manager restructuring'. I added tests and better doc-strings. Over-all I think it's a lot cleaner.

Hey @Zsailer , I was wondering, is there a way or would it make sens to have a way to query the server to know the full-path where it has been launched ?
Alternatively, does it make sens / would it make sens to ask the server to open a notebook by giving it full path in a request. 

Thinking of that because I was thinking of a cl-tool to open notebooks with the server but then I think I woudl need one or the other. 

Anyway, probably not something that is needed in this PR, but just thinking.

Hi @Carreau , there's a method in the notebook manager of this PR called 'get_os_path' which returns the full path where it is launched and any relative path you've added. Is this what your are thinking?

Also, currently in this PR, you can type at the command line:
 `ipython notebook foo/bar/notebook.ipynb`
 and it will open directly to that notebook. In this case, `foo/bar/` is just a relative path appended to the location where the server lives. 

You could also enter this at the command line:
 `ipython notebook --notebook-dir=(server location) /relative/path/to/notebook.ipynb` 
and it will launch the server in 'notebook-dir` and open the named notebook.

there should be a single api request that returns information about the notebook server (path, version, etc.).  We can add information to this reply as it comes up without having to add new URL handlers.

just a get request to something like /api/info or /api/server_info

-MinRK

On Aug 16, 2013, at 13:48, Zachary Sailer notifications@github.com wrote:

> @minrk What would this api request look like?
> 
> A query string to the 'api/notebooks' handlers?
> i.e. GET api/notebooks?server
> 
> The reply is JSON
> 
> {
>     'path': 'path/to/notebook',
>     'version': 3
> }
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
@minrk, thanks for the review on the API tests! Did you run them as well? If so, did they run ok?
Yes, they ran, though they ran extremely slowly. I sent a [pull request](https://github.com/Zsailer/ipython/pull/6) to help make them a bit more efficient.

There are _lots_ of places in this code where it is assumed that urls and paths have the same separator, which is not generally true (e.g. Windows).  We need to be very clear when API functions are expecting file paths and urls, and make sure we are using the right ones and making the appropriate transforms.

In the docstring of every single method that deals with a path, it must be clear whether it is a url path or a file path.

@minrk @Carreau Thanks for the review. I will continue to work on these changes the next couple days. @ellisonbg and I are doing intensive review on this PR on Monday, all day... going through every handler to make sure the design is the way we want it to be. Our focus will mainly be on the web service _design_, not the kind of issues you are seeing... so your review is VERY helpful (any very much appreciated).

My newer commits from our design review will probably break this branch for a day or two until I fix everything. I just thought I'd warn you, in case you update your local branch and try to run tests.
